newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss plan slaughter policy against BSE.
newsitem.headline: Swiss plan slaughter policy against BSE.

text.p: Switzerland plans to spend some 6.5 million Swiss francs ($4.90 million) to slaughter at least 1,500 cows to combat mad cow disease, the government said on Wednesday.
It said in a statement detailing its plans to eradicate Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) in Switzerland that 280 herds of cattle would be affected.
Switzerland has reported 230 cases of BSE, the most of any country except Britain. Scientists suspect tainted beef products can trigger the brain-wasting Creuzfeldt-Jakob Disease in humans.
The measures, which start immediately, cover cows from herds where the disease has been detected and which were born before December 1, 1990, when Switzerland adopted measures to stem BSE.
In addition, herds with any cows born after 1990 that contract the disease in future would be destroyed completely.
The government will pay farmers 90 percent of the estimated value of the slaugthered cow, or 2,500 francs ($1,890) on average.

The Swiss parliament earlier approved the government's plan, a scaled-down version that fell far short of the original proposal to slaughter 230,000 cows, which would have cost tax payers around 320 million francs ($240).
